facts.text: Appeal from the order dated March 3, 1965 of the Punjab High Court, Circuit Bench at Delhi in Execution First Appeal No. 192-C of 1961

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the order dated March 3, 1965 of the Punjab High Court, Circuit Bench at Delhi in Execution First Appeal. No. 192-C of 1961.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by Shah, C. J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, C. J.

facts.text: Jage Ram and two others were lessees of certain property belonging to Mahabir Prasad, his mother Gunwanti Devi and his wife Saroj Devi

anchor.surface_text: Jage Ram and two others-hereinafter companylectively called the defendants-were lessees of certain property belonging to Mahabir Prasad, his mother Gunwanti Devi and his wife Saroj Devi  companylectively referred to hereafter as the plaintiffs.

facts.text: Plaintiffs commenced an action in the court of the Subordinate Judge, First Class, Delhi, for a decree for Rs. 61,750 being the amount of rent due by the defendants

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs companymenced an action in the companyrt of the ,Subordinate Judge, First Class, Delhi, for a decree for Rs. 61,750/being the amount of rent due, by the defendants.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, Delhi decreed the suit

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge, Delhi decreed the suit.

facts.text: Execution of the decree was resisted by the defendants on the plea inter alia that the decree was inexecutable because of the provisions of the Delhi Land Reforms Act, 1954

anchor.surface_text: Execution of the decree was resisted by the defendants on the plea inter alia, that the decree was inexecutable because of the provisions of the Delhi Land Reforms Act, 1954.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge upheld the contention and dismissed the application for execution

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge upheld the companytention and dismissed the application for execution.

facts.text: Mahabir Prasad alone appealed against that order and impleaded Gunwanti Devi and Saroj Devi as party-respondents

anchor.surface_text: Mahabir Prasad alone appealed against that order and impleaded Gunwanti Devi and Saroj Devi as party-respondents.

facts.text: Saroj Devi died in November, 1962

anchor.surface_text: Saroj Devi died in November, 1962,

facts.text: Mahabir Prasad applied that the name of Saroj Devi be struck off from the array of respondents

anchor.surface_text: and Mababir Prasad applied that the name of Saroj Devi be struck of from the array of respondents.

facts.text: High Court made an order granting the application subject to all just exceptions

anchor.surface_text: The High Court made an order granting the application subject to all just exceptions.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the appeal holding that because the heirs and legal representatives of Saroj Devi were not brought on the record within the period of limitation prescribed by the Limitation Act the appeal abated in its entirety

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the appeal holding that because t heirs and legal representatives of Saroj Devi were number brought on the record within the period of limitation prescribed by the Limitation Act the appeal abated in its entirety.

facts.text: Against that order, this appeal is preferred with certificate granted by the High Court

anchor.surface_text: Against that order, this appeal is preferred with certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: The decree in favour of Mahabir Prasad, Gunwanti Devi and Saroj Devi was a joint decree

anchor.surface_text: Ile decree in favour of Mahabir Prasad, Gunwanti Devi and Saroj Devi was a joint decree.

anchor.surface_text: Order 41 r. 4 Code of ,Civil Procedure provides Were there are more plaintiffs or more defendants than one in a suit, and the decree appealed from proceeds on any ground companymon to all the plaintiffs, or to all the defendants, any one of the plaintiffs or of the defendants may appeal from the whole, decree, and thereupon the Appellate Court may reverse or vary the decree in favour of all the plaintiffs or defendants, as the case may be

anchor.surface_text: Even on the alternative ground that Mahabir Prasad being one of the heirs of Saroj, Devi there can be numberabatement merely because numberformal application for showing Mahabir Prasad as an heir and legal representative of Saroj Devi was made. Where in a proceeding a party dies and one of the legal representatives is already on the record in another capacity, it is only necessary that he should be described by an appropriate application made in that behalf that he is also on the record, as an heir and legal representative. Even if there are other heirs and legal representatives and numberapplication for impleading them is made within the period of limitation prescribed by the Limitation Act the proceeding Will number abate.

issues.text: Whether the appeal abated in its entirety because the heirs and legal representatives of Saroj Devi were not brought on the record within the period of limitation prescribed by the Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the appeal holding that because the heirs and legal representatives of Saroj Devi were number brought on the record within the period of limitation prescribed by the Limitation Act the appeal abated in its entirety.

issues.text: Whether the power under Order 41 Rule 4 CPC to reverse or vary the decree in favour of all plaintiffs or defendants can be exercised when the decree proceeds on a ground common to all, the appeal is by one, and the others are impleaded as respondents but one dies without legal representatives being brought on record

anchor.surface_text: Order 41 r. 4 Code of ,Civil Procedure provides Were there are more plaintiffs or more defendants than one in a suit, and the decree appealed from proceeds on any ground companymon to all the plaintiffs, or to all the defendants, any one of the plaintiffs or of the defendants may appeal from the whole, decree, and thereupon the Appellate Court may reverse or vary the decree in favour of all the plaintiffs or defendants, as the case may be Order 41 r. 4 Code of Civil Procedure invests the appellate companyrt with power to reverse or vary the decree in favour of all the plaintiffs or defendants even though they had number joined in the appeal if the decree proceeds upon a ground companymon to all the plaintiffs or defendants.

issues.text: Whether there is abatement of the proceeding where a party dies, one legal representative is already on record in another capacity without formal application to describe that capacity, and other legal representatives are not impleaded within limitation

anchor.surface_text: Even on the alternative ground that Mahabir Prasad being one of the heirs of Saroj, Devi there can be numberabatement merely because numberformal application for showing Mahabir Prasad as an heir and legal representative of Saroj Devi was made. Where in a proceeding a party dies and one of the legal representatives is already on the record in another capacity, it is only necessary that he should be described by an appropriate application made in that behalf that he is also on the record, as an heir and legal representative.

arguments.claim: O.41 r.4 provides that where decree proceeds on ground common to all plaintiffs/defendants, one may appeal the whole decree and appellate court may reverse/vary for all

anchor.surface_text: Order 41 r. 4 Code of ,Civil Procedure provides Were there are more plaintiffs or more defendants than one in a suit, and the decree appealed from proceeds on any ground companymon to all the plaintiffs, or to all the defendants, any one of the plaintiffs or of the defendants may appeal from the whole, decree, and thereupon the Appellate Court may reverse or vary the decree in favour of all the plaintiffs or defendants, as the case may be

arguments.claim: Rameshwar Prasad case is distinguishable because there all plaintiffs filed joint appeal then one died without substitution; here only one decree-holder appealed and impleaded others as respondents

anchor.surface_text: Rameshwar Prasads case 1  is obviously distinguishable from the present case. In Rameshwar Prasads caseall the plaintiffs whose suit had, been dismissed had filed an appeal and thereafter one of them died and his heirs were number brought on the record. In the, present case there is an order against the decree-holders but all the decree-holders did number appeal only one of them appealed and other two were joined as party respondents.

arguments.claim: Following Ratan Lal Shah, appeal maintainable even if co-decree-holder impleaded as respondent dies without legal representatives brought on record; no distinction in principle

anchor.surface_text: In a later judgment of this Court in Ratan Lal Shah v. Firm Lalmandas Chhadammalal Anr.  2  the, plaintiffs obtained a joint decree against two persons-Ratan Lal and Mohan Singh. Against the decree Ratan Lal alone appealed to the High Court of Allahabad. Mohan Singh was impleaded as a party- respondent to the appeal.

holdings.text: Rameshwar Prasad's case is distinguishable from the present case

anchor.surface_text: Rameshwar Prasads case 1  is obviously distinguishable from the present case. In Rameshwar Prasads caseall the plaintiffs whose suit had, been dismissed had filed an appeal and thereafter one of them died and his heirs were number brought on the record. In the, present case there is an order against the decree-holders but all the decree-holders did number appeal only one of them appealed and other two were joined as party respondents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: In Rameshwar all plaintiffs jointly appealed then one died without LRs substituted; here only one appealed with others as respondents

holdings.text: No distinction in principle between Ratan Lal Shah case and present case; appellate court competence under O.41 r.4 not lost merely because joint party made respondent dies without heirs on record

anchor.surface_text: In a later judgment of this Court in Ratan Lal Shah v. Firm Lalmandas Chhadammalal Anr.  2  the, plaintiffs obtained a joint decree against two persons-Ratan Lal and Mohan Singh. Against the decree Ratan Lal alone appealed to the High Court of Allahabad. Mohan Singh was impleaded as a party- respondent to the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy to Ratan Lal Shah where co-decree-holder respondent not served yet appeal maintainable under O.41 r.4; same principle applies even if dies without substitution

holdings.text: Power of appellate court under Order 41 r.4 arises when one of many appeals on common ground; exercisable whether other joint parties not impleaded or impleaded as respondents

anchor.surface_text: Power of the appellate companyrt under Order 41 r. 4 to vary or modify the decree of a Subordinate Court arises when one of the persons out of many against whom a decree or an order had been made on a ground which was companymon to him and others has appealed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual scope of O.41 r.4 allows variation for all on common ground when appealed by one; extends to cases where others impleaded as respondents per precedent

holdings.text: The view taken by the High Court cannot therefore be sustained

anchor.surface_text: The view taken by the High Court cannot therefore be sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in holding O.41 r.4 inapplicable when parties impleaded as respondents and one dies without substitution

holdings.text: No abatement merely because no formal application showing Mahabir Prasad as heir/LR of Saroj Devi; sufficient that one LR already on record in another capacity; no need to implead other LRs within limitation

anchor.surface_text: Even on the alternative ground that Mahabir Prasad being one of the heirs of Saroj, Devi there can be numberabatement merely because numberformal application for showing Mahabir Prasad as an heir and legal representative of Saroj Devi was made. Where in a proceeding a party dies and one of the legal representatives is already on the record in another capacity, it is only necessary that he should be described by an appropriate application made in that behalf that he is also on the record, as an heir and legal representative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Doctrine that proceeding does not abate if one LR on record in different capacity; formal description suffices, other LRs not required

holdings.text: On that ground also the order passed by the High Court cannot be sustained

anchor.surface_text: On that ground also the order passed by the High Court cannot be, sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Alternatively, no abatement under O.22 r.3 and Limitation Act due to Mahabir Prasad already on record as heir

anchor.surface_text: The view taken by the High Court cannot therefore be sustained. Even on the alternative ground that Mahabir Prasad being one of the heirs of Saroj, Devi there can be numberabatement merely because numberformal application for showing Mahabir Prasad as an heir and legal representative of Saroj Devi was made. Where in a proceeding a party dies and one of the legal representatives is already on the record in another capacity, it is only necessary that he should be described by an appropriate application made in that behalf that he is also on the record, as an heir and legal representative.

anchor.surface_text: The view taken by the High Court cannot therefore be sustained. Even on the alternative ground that Mahabir Prasad being one of the heirs of Saroj, Devi there can be numberabatement merely because numberformal application for showing Mahabir Prasad as an heir and legal representative of Saroj Devi was made. Where in a proceeding a party dies and one of the legal representatives is already on the record in another capacity, it is only necessary that he should be described by an appropriate application made in that behalf that he is also on the record, as an heir and legal representative.

anchor.surface_text: In a later judgment of this Court in Ratan Lal Shah v. Firm Lalmandas Chhadammalal Anr.  2  the, plaintiffs obtained a joint decree against two persons-Ratan Lal and Mohan Singh. Against the decree Ratan Lal alone appealed to the High Court of Allahabad. Mohan Singh was impleaded as a party- respondent to the appeal.

The view taken by the High Court cannot therefore be sustained. Even on the alternative ground that Mahabir Prasad being one of the heirs of Saroj, Devi there can be numberabatement merely because numberformal application for showing Mahabir Prasad as an heir and legal representative of Saroj Devi was made. Where in a proceeding a party dies and one of the legal representatives is already on the record in another capacity, it is only necessary that he should be described by an appropriate application made in that behalf that he is also on the record, as an heir and legal representative.
